Table of Contents

Enum RuleScope

Namespace
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums
Assembly
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll

Defines the scope of application for a user-defined rule or filter in the RSS reader. The scope determines which feeds or articles the rule conditions and actions are evaluated against.

public enum RuleScope

Fields

AllFeeds = 0

The rule applies to articles from all subscribed feeds in the user's account.

Behavior:

  • Evaluated against every incoming or existing article, regardless of feed or category.
  • Most common scope for global behaviors (e.g., "star anything mentioning 'AI'").
  • Highest potential performance impact during large syncs.
CurrentView = 3

The rule applies only to articles that are currently visible in the user's active view (based on current filters, search, selected feed/category, unread status, etc.).

Behavior:

  • Evaluated against the current filtered/selected set of articles at the moment of rule execution.
  • Not applied automatically during background sync — typically triggered by explicit user action (e.g., "Apply rules to this view", bulk operations).
  • Fastest scope — only a small subset of articles is considered.
  • Common for temporary/ad-hoc actions (bulk tagging visible results, mark-as-read current page).
  • May behave inconsistently if view changes rapidly; UI should warn or lock scope during application.
SpecificCategories = 2

The rule applies only to articles belonging to one or more selected categories/folders.

Behavior:

  • Requires associated category IDs in the rule definition.
  • Useful when feeds are grouped logically (e.g., "Work", "Hobbies", "News") and rules should respect that grouping.
  • Allows inheritance: articles inherit category from their parent feed if per-article categories are not used.
SpecificFeeds = 1

The rule applies only to articles from a specific list of selected feeds.

Behavior:

  • Requires associated feed IDs in the rule definition.
  • Ideal for feed-specific automation (e.g., auto-archive newsletters, notify on job board updates).
  • More efficient than AllFeeds when targeting few feeds.

Remarks

This enumeration controls the breadth of a rule's influence — from applying globally to all subscribed feeds down to only the currently visible articles in the user's active view. It helps users organize rules efficiently and prevent unintended side effects on unrelated content.

Behavioral impact and system usage:

  • The scope is evaluated at rule execution time (usually during article ingestion or on-demand re-evaluation).
  • Rules with narrower scopes (CurrentView) are typically faster and more targeted.
  • Broader scopes (AllFeeds) affect more articles but may increase processing time during bulk syncs.
  • Scope is independent of conditions — even if conditions match, the article must fall within the scope to apply actions.
  • UI should clearly indicate scope when creating/editing rules (e.g., dropdown: "Apply to all feeds", "Selected feeds only", etc.).

Business rules and recommendations:

  • Default scope for new rules: AllFeeds (broadest, most common for global behaviors like "star articles with keyword X").
  • Use SpecificFeeds or SpecificCategories for feed-specific automation (e.g., archive everything from "Promotions" feed, highlight posts from "Tech News" category).
  • CurrentView is intended for temporary, context-aware rules (e.g., bulk mark-as-read in the current search/filter view, or apply tags to visible selection).
  • When scope is SpecificFeeds or SpecificCategories, the rule configuration must include a list of feed IDs or category IDs; otherwise, the rule is inactive.
  • Rules scoped to CurrentView should only be triggered via explicit user actions (e.g., "Apply rules to current view" button), not automatically on sync.
  • Performance note: Avoid combining very broad scopes with expensive conditions (e.g., regex on AllFields) unless the user base and dataset size justify it.
